declaration.statement: US life expectancy will continue to increase by about 1 year per decade.
declaration.statement_context: Historical trend assumption used in Social Security actuarial models and CDC projections, based on 1980-2014 trajectory.

expected_outcome.description: US life expectancy at birth reaches approximately 79.9 years by 2024
metrics: CDC NCHS life expectancy at birth

operationalization.operationalization_notes: Using CDC NCHS life expectancy at birth as primary metric. Historical 1980-2014 data showed ~1 year increase per decade.

evidence.source_publisher: CDC National Center for Health Statistics
evidence.summary: US life expectancy fell to 76.4 years in 2021, a 2.5 year decline from the 2014 baseline of 78.9 years. Trend reversed, not continued.
evidence.relevance_explanation: Official CDC statistics showing life expectancy decreased rather than increased as the trend assumption projected.

evidence.source_publisher: CDC National Center for Health Statistics
evidence.summary: Life expectancy recovered to 77.5 years in 2022, still 1.4 years below the 2014 baseline and 2.4 years below the projected 79.9.
evidence.relevance_explanation: Shows partial recovery but confirms life expectancy remains well below both baseline and projected trajectory.

resolution.resolution_summary: US life expectancy did not continue increasing. It declined from 78.9 years (2014) to 76.4 years (2021), with partial recovery to 77.5 years (2022) - still well below the projected 79.9 years.
resolution.resolution_details:
Key factors in trend reversal:
1. Opioid epidemic (began affecting life expectancy ~2015)
2. COVID-19 pandemic (2020-2022)
3. Rising 'deaths of despair'

The historical trend assumption failed. This represents a significant actuarial and public health forecasting error.
